ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Noel
Noel Aloysius
Tamara
David Butman
Tamara McMahon
David Butman
Noel
Noel

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The labs were useful, but the field trip was not as helpful as it could have been.

in regards to the labs. At the end we were supposed to be working on a final presentation and final paper and we also had labs to hand in. I found myself frustrated that I was still working on labs when I could be working on the project.

Question 10: Professor Smith and Larry Bonneau do an excellent job organizing this class. I would recommend this course to any resource manager since few other tools exist to assess ecosystem health and human impacts on large scales. An indispensable course.
Learning how to use the software and learning what is possible with remote sensing
The ability to apply the skills to a clinical project was the best part of the course.
Final lab project.
getting a broad overview of applications of remote sensing
Well organized, increasing load, commitment and knowledge of professors, invitation of other professionals...thanks I learned a lot
I now feel confidnt I can use Remote Sensing for various, practical applications

Although the labs were a lot of work there is ultimately no way to get around the fact that they are the best way to learn the material. There are plenty of them to keep you busy and they help you develop an understanding of the wide range of applications possible with remotely sensed data.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More topics for the labs - like air pollution
There is too much work, and not enough time for students to work on their projects.
More time and structured feedback from the instructor is needed for the final projects. I learnt more from the final project than I did from all the labs combined.
i don't know
Please upload the electronic version of the lecture PRIOR to class, so we can take notes.
Less assignments and more lab time to work on final project. Often I felt as though the TAs were there to discipline me rather than help me.....very strange.
None really. There could have been 1 less lab session in order to have more time for final project.

The amount of labs was almost perfect but I would request one or two fewer or at least end labs one or two weeks sooner so that we can go more in depth into the material and the term project. I learn by doing and I felt like there wasn't much time for me to take it all in for the term project. This is an intro course though and I wish to take a more advanced course in the future so for those only wanting to take an intro course the pace and amount of labs might be perfect.
Some of the last few labs (the last two or so) seemed to be just there as busy work. They could be eliminated since we are spending a lot of time already on the final project.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Professor Smith doesn't answer emails, but Larry is very accessible and helpful.
Larry, and Ron to a lesser extent, were always helpful when I had questions, particularly questions relating to my project. Tamara was also helpful during the labs.
Larry was incredibly helpful. TAs were all good, but were net necessarily well-versed in some of the basic techniques that many students had problems with.
remote sensing anlaysis is funny because everyone uses the program differently. A lot of what you need to do means that you have to learn how to do it yourself too.
It was excellent, very committed group of persons.
Responses by instrucors and TA's for help was excellent.
Larry Bonneau is amazing and very helpful. He's available and accessible and understands your question and needs sometimes before you are able to articulate them. Bravo!
Prof. Smith was always responsive to email and made himself extremely available to us. The TA's knew the material well and were always helpful during lab.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I took it to learn what is possible for pollution sensing. I feel like i got even more out of it than I had hoped.
Remote sensing is an extremely useful tool to have. I thought the mix of conceptual/theoretical and practicality in the course was a good one.

this is the only introductory class taught on this subject. I think more courses could be taught in this area in the future - i think it is really important skill that we are underutilizing here at Yale and at FES
Now there is a good chance remote sensing will somehow be incorporated into my final thesis.

I am a Master of Forestry candidate, therefore remote sensing is a great tool to quantify land-use change, types of forest stands, forest health. I would recommend highly recommend this course to any MF - but pretty much any discipline can find some use out this.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I knew that remote sensing would be something that I would use after FES, and I wanted to gain some proficiency in it.
to learn how to analyze environmental features from space
I had to to fulfill a requirement.
It perrtains to my master's research.

At this point in time a resource manager would be at a disadvantage to not know the strengths and weaknesses of the various types of remotely sensed information available. I took this course so that I would not be in that position and to have a solid foundation to utilize these skills in future projects.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: In some ways yes, in other ways no. I have more experience doing it myself than I had hoped, but I don't think we learned much about what is really driving the field forward (cutting edge)
Yes, I learned a lot.
yes
In that it was alot of work.
Yes
Yes absolutely. Great class.
Yes - Very well taught, good pace, great set of skills, lots of reinforcement throughout the course.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
yes.
yes
I got more the I expected.
Yes
yes but would have liked a lab on Seawifs or ocean/coastal related issues.
Yes - we learned some of the most popular uses for remotely sensed data, and various techniques to detect and quantify land-use change.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Expect to work very hard. It is a very time-consuming course.
Keep on top of the work and prioritize this class otherwise you will find yourself swamped in work
Start working on your project early.
Start your final project early and give yourself enough time.

Don't get behind from day one. Do the readings and sometimes re-read when necessary. Take your time with the labs to make sure you completely udnerstand what is going on and make notes for the things you think will be useful during the term project. Keep a log of your term project work and don't be afraid to do a "simple" project as you will most likely learn more that way.

Don't fall behind in the labs too much - they typically take between 3-6 hours to complete on a weekly basis. Also, start your project by mid-February. If not, Mid-terms hit, then spring break and then you're in April...
